Prisoner. Mr. Robinson says there was no other person working be
hind the counting-house but me that day, there was a smith and his boy attending to the boiler in the yard. Witness. I think there was, but not near the counting-house—the chimney of the copper was between them and the prisoner—they could not see into the counting-house from where they were working—they might when they passed by.

SAMUEL HARRIS (police-constable L 177.) On Thursday, the 20th of January, about half-past one o'clock in the day, I was walking in the New Cut, which is no great distance from the prosecutor's premises, and saw the prisoner drunk—in consequence of something that had been told me, I went and took him into custody for being drunk and incapable of taking care of himself—I had not received information about the robbery then—I found on him six sovereigns, a half-sovereign, 3s. in silver, one dozen and a half of spoons, one pepper-castor, and a cream jug, all metal and quite new—about three hours and a half afterwards, when he got better, he was asked in my presence how he came by this money—he said it was an annuity left him by his mother, and he had received at Cockburn's banking-house that day, the sum of 17l.—he said he lodged at the house of Elizabeth Williams, No. 71, Granby-street—I went there that same night, and found a new blue pilot coat, a new suit of moleskin, some new flannel, a boa, some calico, three pairs of stockings, and a piece of toweling—I afterwards went to Mr. Lewis's shop, showed him the moleskin, and got from him this hat, round frock, and pair of trowsers—I produce all the articles—I was present when the prisoner was examined before the Magistrate—I told the Magistrate I had been to Cockburn's to make in
quiry whether the prisoner had an annuity, and whether he received it on that day, and that they had told me no—the prisoner upon that remarked that he was drunk at the time he told me so—this cash-box and book I received from a stranger at Union Hall, on the 20th, who said he had picked them up.

ISAAC LEWIS . I live in the New Cut On Wednesday evening, the 19th of January, the prisoner came to my shop, about a quarter to eight o'clock, and bought a suit of white moleskin and a pilot coat, which came 30s.—he paid me 19s. 6d. and a fourpenny-piece in silver, and four half-to and two 5s. papers of coppers—one packet was halfpence and the other penny-pieces—on Thursday he came again and bought a hat, a pair of trowsers, and a round frock, for which he paid me 26s. in silver and 3d.—the silver consisted of shillings and sixpences—he did not take those things away with him—I had not a hat his size, and he said, "I will pay you for the hat, get me one to fit, and I will call for it to-morrow"—I af
terwards gave the things up to the officer—the suit of moleskin produced is what I sold the prisoner—he had been drinking when he came on Thursday—he was sober on Wednesday.

WILLIAM ARMAN (police-constable M 95.) On Thursday morning, the 20th of January, in consequence of information, I went to No. 71. Granby-street—I found nothing then—in the afternoon I went there again with Harris, and found this moleskin suit, and a number of new
things, which I produce—we took Williams, who was there, to the station—I have since received this bonnet from her.

ELIZABETH WILLIAMS . I live at No. 71, Granby-street, Lambeth. I have known the prisoner near upon a fortnight—on Wednesday evening, the 19th of January, between eight and nine o'clock, I met him near the Corn
wall-road—he gave me a trifle of money that evening—I cannot swear how much, but I should say between 3l. and 4l. in silver—I saw he had some gold, but cannot say how much—I bought a new bonnet and a number of other things with the money, and some he brought himself—he had never given me such a sum of money before, not more than 5s. or. 6s. at the most—he had given me about that much on the Saturday evening—he brought the moleskin-dress, an 1 the pilot-coat himself—the silver he gave me was mostly in shillings, and there were about 2s. worth of. four
penny-pieces, and two or three half-crowns.

JOSEPH CROUCH . I am a carpenter, employed on the prosecutors' pre
mises, and have a little workshop there. On Wednesday, the 19th of January, about half-past five or six o'clock, the prisoner came to my workshop, and asked for a chisel to ease a door—I asked what for, and said he would spoil any door on the premises—he took me to the folding
doors, which are on the flooring of the soap-factory, in a line from my shop to the coppers, and said, "This is what I want to ease"—I told him if he did such a thing, he would injure the door, and I would not allow it—he then left me, and went to work at the coppers—in about half-an-hour I went down stairs to get a pail of soap-ashes, and found him against the counting-house without a light, between the copper and the counting-house—I asked why he was there without a light—he said he did not want one—I said it was very wrong his being there without a light, and then, left him—I had not been up stain above a quarter or half-an-hour, before he came up and wished me good night—that was about a quartet-past six—he then left, and never spoke to a soul there—I followed him with my light, but he shut the folding-doors, and I saw no more of him—the folding-doors are generally open till we all go away, that we may see persons come up the passage, but he shut them, which would prevent my seeing into the passage—we cannot see the counting-house from our door without coming outside—next morning I came to work just after seven, and found the position of two of my screw-drivers altered, placed different to what I had left them when I went away the night before—I went to the counting-house door and found marks on the desk and on the door, ex
ternally and internally, which might have been made by either of those screw-drivers—the door must have been opened from the inside—it could not be opened outside—it throws back—I know the counting-house win
dow well—it is large enough for me to get through.

Prisoner's Defence. I never asked the man for any chisel; there are other men employed on the premises: on the night of the robbery I was off the premises before any of the men left—there was an excise man there the whole day, and that day the collector was late; he was the last person there, I believe; I bid all the men good night when I left, and the boiler saw me out of the gate.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Twelve Months.

836.
CHARLES DICKER was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of June, 1 gelding, price 4l. 15s., the property of
Thomas Miller; and that he, had been before convicted of felony.

GEORGE KING . I am in the employ of Edward Wallis, a horse-slaugh
terer, in Garratt-lane, Wands worth. On the 16th of June the prisoner came to me with a black horse belonging to Mr. Thomas Miller, of Croydon, who is a sand-man, and keeps a beer-shop. I know his master very well—his Christian name is Thomas—I lent him another horse to go home with as be said he had left his own in our field—he left Miller's black horse in our field, and said to me, "What can you give me for the other horse?" meaning Miller's black one—I told him to tell his master I would allow him 55s. for it—next morning he came and brought my horse back, saying he would take the money I had bid him—I sealed the money up in a letter, put a note inside it, and gave him 1s. for himself—he went down towards Wandsworth, and tied his horse, which he had brought with mine, up at a sign-post, and went away with the money—I gave him the money to de
liver to his master, believing he had authority to sell the horse—it was the black horse which had been turned out into the field—my master's daughter wrote a note with the money.

THOMAS MILLER . I keep a beer-shop and am a broom-maker; I live at Croydon. On the 17th of June the prisoner left my service—I was not aware of his bargaining for the sale of one of my horses—I never autho
rized him to sell the black horse—he never brought me the money for it—I had sent him to Wandsworth on the 16th with a cart and two horses, and he brought Wallis's horse home, saying the black horse was knocked up, and appeared ill, and Mr. Wallis bad lent him a horse to bring home, which he must return about ten or eleven next morning—I said, "Well, be punctual, and get there in time"—I tied Wallis's horse behind my cart, and expected him home at night, but Wallis's man came over, and said be had bought the horse—I did not see the prisoner again till he was in custody.

WILLIAM LEE . In consequence of information I received, I went to the shop of Townsend, a clothes-dealer, in High-street, Wandsworth—I saw a note taken out of the pocket of a pair of trowsers there, by the shopman, which I produce—I cannot identify the trowsers—the shopman has left.

WILLIAM REED . I apprehended the prisoner at Brixton-hill—I made Aim no promise, but cautioned him if he said anything, I must state it before the Magistrate—he acknowledged that he had absconded with the money, and hoped if he got over this, he should not do anything more wrong.

GEORGE KING
re-examined. The note produced by Lee is what I sent by the prisoner with the money—(read)—"Sir,—I have sent the money for the horse, as agreed on yesterday, 2l. 15s., which you will find enclosed."

Prisoner's Defence. The policeman told me I had better tell what I had done with the money, or I should be sorry for it; this was an old horse, which master bought at a sale; it fell down four times, when the cast was empty; when I came to Wallis's with a load of bricks, it fell again; people said I should never get home with it; King said, "As I know your master, I will lend you a horse to go home, and will turn yours into my field;" he told me to tell my master what he would give for the horse; I told my mis
tress; she said she would sooner have the one I had brought than her own; and in the morning, master said he thought of selling it at Smithfield;

when I got back, master's horse laid dead in the field, and I took the money for it; there was no water in the trough; as I was getting some out of the river, I slipped in up to my middle, with the paper I had the money in; as I went up the lane, I dropped the paper with the money; a cart wheel ran over it, and cut the paper asunder; I had dropped some of the money in the river, and had 30s. left; I bought a pair of trowsers, and having a bad master, (who even suffered me at night to turn his horses into other farm
er's fields, and had kicked me down eight steps a few days before,)I thought I should be made a bigger thief than I am; I never received a farthing of money, and was with him five weeks.
THOMAS MILLER . I said nothing to induce him to say anything.

GEORGE KING
re-examined. The hone was not dead when he came in the morning—it was down, and in a dreadfully bad state—it was dying, but it laid the next day and night before it died—there was grass in the meadow where it was—it died in the field—I knew it would not live when be came for the money—its lungs were gone, and it was rotten altogether.

THOMAS MILLER
re-examined. I have no reason to know that he said anything about the horse to my wife—he said something of this sort at Wandsworth—I had no idea that he had sold it—I never turn my horses out of a night—I took the prisoner out of charity, and paid him 18d. a night.
JACOB CALMUT (police-constable P 190.) I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction, from Mr. Lawson, the Clerk of the Peace for Surrey—(read)—I know the prisoner to be the person.

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined One Year.

837.
ELLEN DALEY was indicted
for stealing, on the 11th of Ja
nuary, 3 pints of gin, value 3s.; and 2 bottles, value 4d.; the goods of
John Watkins, her master.

JOHN WATKINS . I keep the Goat's-head public-house in the Wands
worth-road—the prisoner was my cook for about three months. On going into my cellar on the 11th of January, I discovered a quantity of gin on the floor under a vat, and found the key of that vat on the top of an ad
joining vat, with the handle wet, as if just laid down by a wet hand—I went into the kitchen, and found two bottles of gin in the meat-screen—I placed them in the same situation in which I found them, and with Trim
mings, my son-in-law, retired into a little dairy adjoining the kitchen, to watch—Trimmings got on a chair, so as to look over the top of the door, where there is a blind—in a short time the prisoner came into the kitchen, opened the door of the meat-screen, took out the two bottles of gin, placed them under her apron, and was about to take them out of the kitchen-door into the yard—she went across the kitchen to go out—I then came out of the dairy, stopped her at the door, and said, "Mary, these two bottles of gin belong to me"—I took them from her, sent for a policeman, and she was taken into custody—her room was searched, but nothing of mine found.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Is there a dresser in the kitchen? A. Yes—I have a pot-boy—the prisoner and he have not had any quar
rel to my knowledge—I never heard that the prisoner was called down into the kitchen, with directions that there was a goose to be roasted—she had no notice of her trunks being searched—I had as good a character with her as a girl need to have.

WILLIAM WILSON . I am pot-man to the prosecutor—my master ordered me to wash some wine bottles on the 10th of January—I washed three dozen—I missed two bottles—they were such as these which contain the gin—I cannot swear they are the bottles, but they are similar.
Cross-examined. Q. Have you ever had any quarrel with the prisoner A. No—I swear that—I know nothing of her being called down to roast a goose.

EDWARD WIGGINS . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner, and re
ceived these two bottles at the prosecutor's bar.

JOHN WATKINS
re-examined. The prisoner said nothing when I stopped her with the bottles, but was very much confused—the outside of the bottles were very wet—I did not discover that her apron was wet—I do not keep my cellar-door open—the prisoner had applied for the key to my son—he is not here.
NOT GUILTY .

838.
JAMES ATKINSON, alias John Smith,
was indicted
for felo
niously, and without lawful excuse, being at large within Her Majesty's dominions, before the expiration of the term for which he had been ordered to be transported.

BARTHOLOMEW HERRING (police-constable P 187.) I produce a certi
ficate which I received from Mr. Straight, the deputy clerk of Assize—I saw Mr. Straight sign it—it is his signature—I took the prisoner into custody in company with my brother officer, on the 28th of December last, at his father's house, in the parish of St. Mary, Newington, in the county of Surrey—I asked him what his name was—he said, "John Smith"—I told him he was taken for being at large before the end of the term of his sentence for which he was transported—he said, "I was never out of the country in my life"—I searched him, and found on him some files in a box with some lucifers—I saw this handkerchief with him coming along, and also some skeleton keys—(the certificate was here read, stating that the prisoner had been ordered to be transported for life.)

GEORGE GOFF . In December, 1828, I was a constable of St. Mary's, Lambeth—I was at Kingston Assizes that month, and saw the prisoner there—I was present at his trial—another man, named John Wigg, was tried with him—I was in court when sentence of death was ordered to be recorded—I had known him before, and am quite sure he is the man who was then convicted, and sentenced—he was tried before Mr. Baron Vaughan, or Mr. Justice Burrows, I do not know which—they were both there at the time.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Before Sir James Burrows, was it? A. I think it was—I am not certain which it was—I had two cases there, and one was tried before one Judge, and one before the other—one case was for robbing Judge Bay ley's sister, Mrs. Hankey—it was in 1828—I went down on the Saturday as the Assizes began, and they finished on Thursday, the 1st of January—the prisoner is altered—he is older, but there is something about him by which I should know him—he is altered in colour, according to the length of time he has been gone, but not so very much—when I saw him at Union-hall, the officers told me he had been up twice before—if there is anything due to me for this, I expect to get

whatever there is—I know there was formerly an Act of Parliament where there was a reward—I do not know whether there is now—I did not come into office till the rewards were put an end to—I was sworn in in 1817, and left in 1831 or 1832, on account of the new police being established—when I applied for my warrant to be renewed, they told me I was not wanted—I was not a constable of Union-hall, only as an extra-constable to assist the others—I was never on the establishment—I do not know that there was any other reason for my leaving—I had no fault found with me—I was never accused of anything—I gave evidence against a few men for the Mint—my conduct with respect to coin was never investigated to my knowledge—no fault was ever found with me to my face—I did not say when the prisoner was shown to me, that he was so much altered I should not have known him, nor any thing to that effect—that I swear—I am quite positive of him—I have not been inquiring about what money will be coming to me—I swear that—I have not been to the Secretary of State's office to inquire about any reward—I went there about a week or a fortnight ago—there was no quarrel between me and any other person about the way in which we were to get the money.
MR. DOANE. Q. What did you go to the Secretary of State's office for? A. To ask whether there was any account of this man's having deserted, because I would not make any mistake.

ROBERT COLE . I am a watchman in the County jail, at Horsemonger-lane. I remember the prisoner being brought to the jail, in 1828, with John Wigg—I cannot exactly say the date—I remember the Assizes being held at Kingston—it was before the Assizes that he was brought—I saw him go down to the Assizes, and I saw him after the Assizes—I took him on board the Dolphin bulk, at Chatham, with other convicts—I was one of the guards—the prisoner is the man.

Cross-examined. Q. You recollect him perfectly, do you? A. Very well—he looks rather darker, and older than he did in 1828, but there is no difference in his features—I went before the Magistrate on this charge, and stated that I knew him—I did not express the least hesitation, or say that I should not have known him—I knew him him directly I saw him.

RICHARD MYERS . In 1828 I was a constable. I was at the Assizes at Kingston in December that year—I took the prisoner down in a van among a number of others—I had known him for a number of years be
fore—I was present at his trial, and brought him from the Sessions-house to the jail—I have no doubt in the world that he is the man.

Cross-examined. Q. When did you cease to be an officer? A. When the new police came in force, that was the reason—I sent my warrant in—I was a parish-constable—I used not to be employed by the Mint—I used to go there occasionally—there was no investigation about my conduct—I was in business as a tobacconist, but have retired these two years—I have lived in the same house thirty years.

GUILTY . Aged 32.—
Confined Six Months, and then
Transported for Life.

839.
JOHN BENNETT was indicted
for feloniously and knowingly uttering, on the 12th of January, a forged request for the delivery of goods, with intent to defraud
Richard Moser the elder, and another.

JOHN BILL . I am clerk to Richard Moser, senior, and another, iron
merchants,

No. 165, Borough. I know the prisoner, he has come to our firm three or four times for steel—on the 12th of January I saw him there—it is my duty to make out the invoices, which I did for these goods—I do not know that the prisoner spoke to me—he presented me with a written order for the goods now produced—he said nothing—be
lieving it to be genuine, I made out a bill for two bundles of spring-steel, 3l. 12s.—I do not remember his saying any thing—he took the steel away—he had had goods before—not on his own account.

Prisoner. I did not have the steel, and never made out the order—I was on board a steam-boat at the time. Witness. I am sure he is the man, I know he went away with the steel—I cannot recollect whether he took it on his shoulder or in a truck—he must have had a truck, it weighed 2cwt. lqr.—I am certain he is the man.

JEMIMA DRY . I am a widow, and carry on the business of a wheel
wright and smith, in Horse and Groom-yard, Westminster. The prisoner was in my employ five years ago, as hammerman to his father, who worked for me—I have not seen him since—he was discharged five years ago—I dealt with Messrs. Moser then, and do so now—this order is not my writing—I never authorised any body to write it for me, and none of the goods ever came to my premises.

WILLIAM MORRISS . I am porter to Moser and Son. I know the pri
soner, and have seen him at our premises more than three times—I can
not state the date, but I have seen him twice since Christmas—I delivered some steel to him on a Tuesday, the last time he came, but I know no
thing about the order now produced—it was another order—I cannot recollect the transaction of the 12th of January—I know nothing of the delivery of these goods myself—we have no other customer named Dry—(order read)—"12th January, 1842. Please let the bearer hare two bundles of spring steel.—J. DRY."
GUILTY . Aged 22.

840.
JOHN BENNETT was again indicted
for feloniously and know
ingly uttering, on the 27th of January, a forged order for the delivery of goods, with intent to defraud
Richard Moser the elder, and another.

WILLIAM MORRISS . I am a yard porter to Messrs. Moser. I know the prisoner by sight—I am positive of him—he brought me this order on the 27th of January, and asked me to look out the steel for him—I said, "Your people are using a great deal of steel, and you tell young master Dry to be more careful in his writing; he is getting a worse scholar now than before he went to school"—the prisoner said young Dry was a bad scholar—I selected the steel in consequence of the order, weighed it, and our yard clerk had it to enter, and gave him the invoice—I am posi
tive he is the man—I delivered the steel to him, helped him tie it up, and he took it away on his shoulder—it was under 56lbs.

JOHN BILL . I am clerk to the prosecutors. On the 27th of January the prisoner came, I ticked this order, and gave him the invoice—it came to 2l. 11s. 6d., weighing 2qrs. 91bs.—be took it away on his shoulder—I noticed the order at the time—it was signed "J. Dry," which Mrs. Dry generally signs.

JEMIMA DRY . This paper is not my writing, nor my son's—I never authorised anybody to write it—my son is not in the habit of drawing these orders, and if he did, he always signed my name as well as his own—I always sign Jemima in full.

Prisoner's Defence. I met a man at the Marsh-gate, who said be would give me 2s. to go and get this steel, while he went to see somebody down the New-cut; I went and brought him the steel; he gave me 2s.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Transported for Ten Years.
(There were five other indictments against the prisoner.)

841.
WILLIAM GINBY and
DOROTHY GINBY were indicted for
feloniously receiving of a certain evil-disposed person, on the 15th of Ja
nuary, 1 watch, value 10l.; 1 coat, value 2l.; 1 waistcoat, value 10s.; 1 pair of trowsers, value 1l.; 2 toilet covers, value 2s.; 1 shift, value 2s.; 1 petticoat, value 3s.; and 1 shirt, value 1s. 6d.; the goods of
James Hunt Burgess; well knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

ELIZABETH BURGESS . I am the wife of James Hunt Burgess, a lighter
man, of Grange-walk, Bermondsey. On Saturday, the 15th of January, I went out about six o'clock in the evening—nobody was left in the house—the windows and door were fastened—I returned in about an hour and a quarter by myself, unlocked the door, and fell over a candlestick in the passage—I got a light, and found the front-parlour very much disordered—I missed a table-cover and a brown mantle out of the front parlour, and from other parts of the house a gold watch, a coat, a pair of trowsers, a waistcoat, a shirt, seven shifts, two petticoats, three night-gowns, two toi
let-covers, one black mantle, and an Orleans cloth dress—on Tuesday, the 18th, I saw them again at the police-office—I had seen them all in the house at six o'clock on Saturday night.

JAMES HUNT BURGESS . On the 15th of January I came home shortly after eight o'clock, and missed the things—I had some bills left at Mr. Marchant's, the pawnbroker—on Monday evening I received a communi
cation from him, went there, and saw my watch—while I was there the female prisoner came in to pledge a coat—I did not bear what she said, nor see what she brought—a policeman was sent for—I went to the station with her, and thence to her residence, with a policeman, (leaving her at the station)—we there found the male prisoner—it is a general dealer's shop—we searched the house—I found up stairs, in a drawer in a bed-room, a shift, a petticoat, a shirt, and a toilet-cover of mine, and on the drawers another toilet-cover—the male prisoner was taken into custody.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did you hear the policeman tell him that he had come to search his house, and that his wife was in custody for felony? A. No—he was admitted to bail by the Magistrate, and surrendered to-day.

JOHN HENRY SYMES . I am in the employ of Thomas Marchant, a pawnbroker. On Saturday, the 15th of January, the female prisoner came about eight o'clock in the evening, and pawned a suit of clothes—about an hour after my employer took a gold watch in pawn from her, in my presence—on the 17th we received a printed bill respecting the property stolen, and finding the watch described, I sent our boy to inform Burgess, who came; and while I was showing him the watch, the female prisoner came to pawn a coat and handkerchief—I was told the prisoner was in the shop while I was speaking to Burgess, and I gave her into custody—I left the watch in the care of Mr. Marchant—I have brought it here.

Cross-examined. Q. Is it gold? A. Yes—the female prisoner was dressed much as she is now, with the exception of a bonnet—the watch is worth about 7l.—she had 2l. 10s. on it—30s. on the 15th, and 1l. mote on the Monday—the 15th was the first transaction I had with her.

JOHN HUNT . I am a policeman. I took the female prisoner in charge, and took her to the station—I there saw the duplicate of the suit of clothes taken from her by the female searcher—she tried to get it from the searcher—I was outside the door, and heard arguments arising between them—she was resisting its being taken from her, and I took it.

JAMES TIDMARSH . I am a policeman. On the evening of the 17th of January I saw the female prisoner in charge—I knew her before, and where she lived—I went with Burgess to the house, and saw the male prisoner—I told him I had come to search his house, his wife was in cus
tody for felony—he seemed surprised, and said he did not know she was out—I searched the house, and found this property, which the prosecutor identified.

Cross-examined. Q. How far is the Mint in the Borough from where Burgess lives? A. About a mile and a quarter—the male prisoner came up stairs with us, and showed us all over the house—I went to the home three times, and searched every time—the first time was within about seven or eight minutes only—the second might be a quarter of an hour—the pro
perty was on the first floor—the prisoner said it was his and his wife's bed
room—there are two more bed-rooms, one occupied by three of the chil
dren, and the top room by a brother, who was in bed.

Q. You found him at home each time you went to search? A. Yes—I saw the things the first time I went, and went back for Mr. Burgen—I took some things away the first time, and saw the others there—I took them away the third time—he lighted me up stairs—I did not know what was stolen the first time—I found them in the same place when I went again—the male prisoner is a milkman.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

WILLIAM GINBY—
NOT GUILTY .

DOROTHY GINBY—
GUILTY . Aged 30.-
Confined Twelve Month.

842.
HENRY SUMMERSALL was indicted
for stealing, on the 30th of December, 1 sovereign, 3 half-sovereigns, 4 crowns, 8 half-crowns, and 30 shillings, the monies of
Anthony Ferderer, in the dwelling-house of
Ra
chael Davies.

ANTHONY FERDERER . I am a clock-maker, and live in St. Andrew's row, New Kent-road—I have known the prisoner for some years. On Christmas eve he brought a customer to my house for a clock, and another on the Monday evening—he asked for a Christmas box—I gave him a German silver chain from a drawer, which I opened—the chain caught against a paper containing money, and four or five half-crowns fell out—the pri
soner said, "I wish I had got that money"—I said, I wished I bad some more, there was not much—he came again on the Tuesday with another customer—he bad left me half-a-crown on the first clock—I got nothing more—the customers were to pay 1s. a week for the clocks, and when they could afford it, 2s.—the first clock was 2l.—the other two 35s. each—I was to call on the prisoner's father, where he lodged, for the first instalment—I did not get any thing—he was not at home the first time

—the second time he told me he did not know the people, except he saw them in the street, and I must go and find them out—I scolded him—on going home, on Thursday evening, in consequence of what was said to me by a lodger, I looked into my drawer, and missed the money stated—(I had seen it safe on Wednesday)—it was in the same drawer I had given him the chain from, in the front-parlour—I had rolled all the money up is the same paper on the Wednesday evening, and placed it at the back of the drawer—Hofmire works in that room for himself.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How long have you known the prisoner? A. Two years—I have known hit parents nearly seven—I sold a clock to them two years ago—he came to my house occasionally—I let him have the clocks for the people, as I thought it was all right—I knew he lived with his father—I have seen him there many times—I have not dined or drank tea there—I have been in the habit of doing business with his father for even years—I never kept my money-drawer locked—I ex
pected nobody would come to my room—Hofmire went to the room when
ever he liked, and so did Rachael Davies, the landlady—there are no ser
vants—I make my own bed—I have two rooms—I keep my parlour-door locked, and put the key in the landlady's kitchen—I had seen the prisoner on the Thursday morning—be never came to my house before Christmas eve, and three times after—his father has had two clocks and a watch since I have known him.

JOSEPH HOFMIRE . I am a clock-maker, and live with Ferderer—we occupy the same room to work in, and pay the rent of the front-parlour between us—I have a bed-room up stairs—I was there the second time the prisoner came, when he asked for a Christmas-box, and heard him say be should like the money very much—on the "Thursday I met him at the end of St. Andrew's-row, about half-past four o'clock—he said, "How do you do?"—I said, "Very well; how is it you have been over here?"—he said, "I want to see Mr. Ferderer very particularly, about them clocks he sold"—I said, "You have been in our place"—he said, "Yes, Mr. Ferderer is not at home, I will go back with you and wait till he comes home"—the lodger up stairs let us in—I went in, fetched the key from the kitchen, and let him into the workshop—I found the door locked—I lighted the fire, and the prisoner sat down close to the prosecutor's drawer—I knew there was money there—I put the kettle on the fire and began working—a woman in the next room called out to me, "I have got a good fire, if you want to put your kettle on"—so I went into the other room and put it on—I then went up stairs, leaving the prisoner in the work-room—I came down in a few minutes, and found the prisoner at the street-door, ready to go out—I said, "Are you not going to stop till Mr. Ferderer comes home?"—he said, "No, I had rather go to a public-house and have a pint of beer and smoke a pipe, and be back in half an hour"—I said, "If you want some beer I will get you some, you can smoke a pipe here, or you can have tea with me"—he said he had rather go to a public-house, and be back in half an hour—he left about five o'clock, and did not return—Ferderer came in about half-past five—in consequence of what I told him he went to his drawer and missed his money—I had seen the paper containing the money that morning, when I took a gimlet out of the drawer, after Ferderer went out—it had the usual appearance of having money in it—when I went out I shut and locked the workshop—there is no door opens from the workshop to the other room—you must go out into the passage—

the woman had seen me come in—when J went out I had hung the key on a nail in the kitchen, which I usually do—the prisoner did not call out to me—when I came down he had the latch of the street-door in his band to go out.

Cross-examined. Q. He stood talking to you in the hall, awhile, did he not? A. Yes—the street-door was not kept open, but any body could pull it open—when I saw the paper in the morning, I saw that it had something rolled in it—I had seen the paper the Wednesday before, when he took the chain out—it was in the back part of the drawer—I pulled the drawer about half out to get the gimlet, which was in the middle of it—the drawer is only about half a foot long, and half a foot wide—I cannot think of the name of the lodger who let us in—it was not the landlady—it was the woman up stairs—(looking at his depositions)—this is my name and handwriting—(the witness's depositions being read, stated "the landlady then opened the street-door to us")—I did say before the Magistrate that the landlady let us in—I forgot it—it was three weeks afterwards.

JURY. Q. Was it the same person who let you in that offered to boil your kettle on her fire? A. No—that was the woman in the back par
lour—I do not know whether she spoke from the passage or her room—there are two lodgers, both married women and their husbands live in the house.

RACHAEL DAVIES . I am a widow, and lire in Clarence-terrace, St. Andrew's-row. I am the landlady of the house, and the witnesses lodge there, and two others—one of them has two rooms up stairs, and one down stairs—they are married—Mr. and Mrs. Sherwin lodge in the two rooms up stairs, and a man and his wife in the back-room—I cannot speak the name—the two witnesses have the front workshop, and a room up stairs—I have no servant—when the two witnesses go out, they lock their door and bring the key to me—I put it into my room, which we call the kitchen, and keep it till they come back at night—nobody could get at it when I was at home—when I was out they might—on the Thursday I was at home all day—I was at home about five o'clock—I had not been out at all—I work in the kitchen when I am at home—I go in and out to the yard—I do not take the key with me—I never lock the kitchen door—the key was safe all day—Ferderer went out between eight and nine in the morning, and Hofmire directly after—I was in the kitchen, as near as I can say, from nine to five—pretty nearly all that time—I was in the kitchen when Hofmire came in for the key—as far as I know, nobody had had it since he went out in the morning—nobody could get into the work
shop without my hearing them—it is a small house—the key was left in my care—I do not know who let Hofmire in at five—I did not—the lady up stairs did, as they say—the two female lodgers were at home at five—I heard the knock at the door, and one of them let him in—I cannot say who it was.

Cross-examined. Q. When were you examined? A. This day week—I was not at the police-office when Hofmire was examined—when he came home from the office they told me I had let him in, and I said it was a mistake—Ferderer did not say so, it was one Joseph—the other lodg
ers never lock their doors—one of them is a porter at Charing-cross—the other was out of work, and had been for some time—he be
longed to a steam-vessel—I was in my own room pretty nearly all day—I did not stay in it entirely—I cannot recollect how often I went into

the yard—I was washing in the kitchen, and I hung the things in the kitchen to dry—I do not think I went a dozen times into the yard—I will not swear it—there is only one flight of stairs in the house—one lodger lives below and one above—the two witnesses have the other room up stairs—I never saw the prisoner there—the key hung on a peg in the kitchen, and I mostly hang a cloth over it, but not always, or a shawl or a bonnet—I never missed the key from the time it was given me till he came for it—the Magistrate did not require the other lodgers to attend—the one that let Hofmire and the prisoner in, went with me, and the Magistrate said she was not wanted.

JOHN BARKER (police-constable K 108.) I took the prisoner into custody on the 20tb of January, in Whitechapel-road—I told him he was wanted at Mile-end station—he said very well, he would go—I said it was respecting some money over the water—he said he knew nothing about it—on going a little further, he said he bad heard of it, but knew nothing about it.
NOT GUILTY .

843.
FREDERICK SPICER was indicted
for assaulting
Elizabeth Stoot; with intent, &c.

GUILTY of a Common Assault. Aged 30.—
Confined Two Months.

844.
GEORGE BYNON was indicted
for stealing, on the 8th of Ja
nuary, 140lbs. weight of coals, value 1s. 6d., the goods of
Thomas White, in a vessel on the navigable river Thames; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Three Months.

845.
WILLIAM BAKER was indicted
for embezzling 2l., the monies of
Benjamin Sapsford, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Confined Six Months.

846.
WILLIAM FEWKES was indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of January, 5 sovereigns, 2 half-sovereigns, 2 half-crowns, and 3 shillings, the monies of
John Fewkes: and
HENRY CONNORTON
, for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

JOHN FEWKES . I keep a shop in John-street, Waterloo-road, Lam
beth—William Fewkes is my son—he absented himself from me on the 6th of January, and I lost five sovereigns, two half-sovereings, two half-crowns, and three shillings, from a box in my kitchen—my three girls slept in the bed in the kitchen, and the prisoner slept at the foot of it in a chair—the box was broken open—it had been safe at eleven o'clock the night before—I gave notice at the police-station—I went to Greenwich, and when I came back, a boy told me that my son and Connorton had been seen to
gether—I went to Connorton's father on the Sunday morning after—I Connorton there—he said he had seen my boy, and that he had 6l. 8s.—I said, "Did he tell you where he got it?"—he said, "Yes, he said he took it from you"—I said, "Where did you get those new boots you have on?"—he said, "I bought them, and I got the money honestly"—I gave him in charge—he told the inspector that this was all he bad out of the money—the Magistrate could not commit him till I took my son, and when I found my son, I took Connorton again.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. When you saw Connorton first, you told him he had better tell you all about it? A. I did not—I asked him if he had seen my boy, and what money he had with him—I never told him that my boy had been robbing me—I never saw him till I took him—I did not tell him I was the father of Fewkes—he must have known me, because he bad been whistling at nights after my boy—my lodger has seen him do so.

COURT. Q. You missed this money? A. Yes, and have not found any of it—I have had no conversation with my son—when he was at Union-hall he would not speak to me—nobody but my son could have taken this money—it is impossible, as they must have pulled him out of bed to get to the box—he slept nearly on the box, and he set off that morning at seven o'clock—his mother was not dressed.

GEORGE BEATTY (police-constable L 80.) I took the prisoner Fewkes—he said he gave Connorton half the money—they would not acknowledge it till they went before the Magistrate—there they confessed it—Connorton acknowledged that the boots were bought for him out of the money—Fewkes made a statement before the Magistrate—I know Mr. Traill's hand
writing—this is his writing to this deposition.

Cross-examined. Q. Who is Mr. Traill? A. The Magistrate at Union
hall—I was at the office that day, and I think I have been there three or four times before, or oftener—I have been three years in the police—I do not remember how often I had been before Mr. Traill before this case—I had been once before—that was about a man who stole a cheese—I think that was twelve months ago or better—I think I saw Mr. Traill write on that occasion—I am not quite sure—I have seen him write more than once, but I do not remember when—I have seen him write on other cases as well as my own—I saw him write on the 25th of January—he was sitting on the bench where he always sits—I was standing nearly opposite to him—I cannot tell what he wrote—I saw him write, and it was handed into my own hand afterwards—I saw the certificate of the notice I got, which he signed—I have it here—I have seen him write several times before—his Christian name is James—I am sure about that—(read)—"The prisoner Fewkes says, I confess to taking the money. The prisoner Connorton I went with Fewkes and bought a pilot-coat, and after that, he di
vided says, his money with me; I had two sovereigns in gold, and some other money."

FEWKES-
GUILTY . Aged 12. CONNORTON-
GUILTY. Aged 12.

847.
RICHARD LIGHT was indicted
for bigamy.

SUSAN HUGHES . In 1823, I lived in the neighbourhood of Shrewsbury—I knew Mr. Eaton, of Claremont-buildings, there—the prisoner was in Mr. Eaton's service as footman—I remember in 1823, there was a young woman with whom he kept company, Emma Maria Fox—I knew her—the prisoner asked me to go to church with him and Emma Fox—I said, "I suppose you are going to be married?"—he said, "Yes"—I said, Ann Davis would rather go (Ann Davis is now dead) I did not go—the prisoner was often talking of his marriage, and so was Ann Davis too

—they were married at the church of St. Chad, at Shrewsbury—the prisoner told me so—he said the minister's name was Mr. Sandford—they afterwards went to live at her brother's, Richard Fox's, in New-street—they lived together as man and wife—I saw them together after, and they have been at our house together—I left the prisoner at Mr. Eaton's—I saw Emma Fox after the prisoner said he was going to church-—I saw her wedding-ring on the fourth finger—they lived together in Edom-place—I saw Emma Fox alive last Thursday four weeks, at Manchester.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Do you know how long they lived together? A. No—I saw Emma Fox at Manchester—she was living with her husband, whose name is Bell—she is married now—I went to see whether she was alive—Mr. Barnes sent me—he is an architect—she said she was very comfortable.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Do you know whether she is married to Bell? A. No.

WILLIAM BARNES . I produce a copy of the register of marriage from St. Chad's, Shrewsbury—I examined it myself with the register of mar
riages—I am related by marriage to Margaret Turner Thompson—I pro
secute this case—I took this certificate down to Shrewsbury by order of Mr. Traill, and found the parish clerk—the register was open—I compared this copy with the book, and Mr. Webster did the same, and signed it—I will swear it is a true copy—(reads)—"Richard Light, of this parish, bachelor, and Emma Fox, of this parish, spinster, were married in this church by banns, this 16th of July, 1823, by me, Thomas Landford, minister. "WILLIAM SPEAK,"
In the presence of "ANN DAVIS. "

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Before you had obtained this, had you seen the prisoner? A. Yes, on the 3rd of August, at my house—he made a state
ment to me, which I took down in writing at the time—he said he was married at St. Chad's on the 16th of July, 1823; that he married Emma Fox, a dress-maker, by whom he had three children, and one was dead; that he left his wife and two children in Manchester, that be had agreed to leave them, and never see them again—he stated that William Speak and Ann Davis were witnesses to the marriage, and that the clergyman was Mr. Landford.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Had you made him any promise that he should not be prosecuted? A. No—I swear he made the state
ment without my giving him any inducement—I told him I should make use of the evidence against him—his third wife, Butler, was present.

GEORGE YARROW . I am parish clerk of Shoreditch. I produce the register of marriages for that parish—I have the entry of a marriage of Richard Light with Margaret Turner Thompson—(read)—"Marriage so
lemnized in the parish of Shoreditch, No. 268, 23rd November, 1837. Richard Light and Margaret Turner Thompson, both full age, bachelor and spinster, servants; Light living in New North-street, and Thompson in Well-street; and signed by them in presence of George Yarrow and Je
mima Trance."
MARGARET TURNER THOMPSON . I have known the prisoner since 1832—I went through the ceremony of marriage with him at Shoreditch church, on the 23rd of November, 1837—we were married by banns—he
described himself as a single man—he lived two years and a fortnight with me, and then left me.

Cross-examined. Q. How long had you known him? A. Since 1832—he lived at Crosby, five miles from Liverpool—he was living with Mrs. Luce, in George-square, Liverpool—we never lived in the same house together before we were married—I have lived in James-street, Buckingham gate—I was seduced by him, and clung to him till he married me—we lived together for two years before we were married—I lived with him because he promised me marriage.

GEORGE WARNER (City police-constable, No 325.) I took the prisoner on the 12th of December, in Lombard-court, Fleet-street—I found him on a roof of a house behind a stack of chimnies—I said I must take him—he said, "No, don't; go back, and say you can't find me"—I said I had been looking after him some time, and it was more than I dare do—I had a warrant to take him—he said, "I suppose it is about Margaret Tur
ner's marriage?"—I said, "Yes, you must go with me"—he still refused to come off the roof, and after persuading him some time I got hold of him by the collar—he said, sooner than he would go he would rather throw us both down, and break our necks—the distance was from thirty to forty feet—after some persuasion I succeeded in taking him.
Cross-examined. Q. Could he not have brought you both down? A. It would not have taken a great deal of trouble—he was alone on the roof.
GUILTY . Aged 42.

848.
RICHARD LIGHT was again indicted
for bigamy.

SUSAN HUGHES . I was in Shrewsbury in 1832—I knew the prisoner at Mr. Eaton's—the prisoner asked me to go to church—I said, "Ann Davis would rather go"—he was often talking of that marriage—the ac
count I gave in the last case is correct.

WILLIAM BARNES . I produce a copy of the marriage register, and it is correct—the prisoner called on me, and said he was married at St. Chad's, on the 16th of July, 1823, to Emma Fox, a dress-maker, by whom he had three children, that one was dead, and that he left his wife and two children in Manchester.

GEORGE TURNER . I am parish clerk of St. Peter, Walworth, in St. Mary, Newington. I have the marriage register, in which there is an entry that on the "18th February, 1840, (No. 284) Richard Light and Hannah Butlin, of full age, widower and spinster, by trade a grocer, were married in this church. (Witness)
"GEORGE TURNER, ANN BAILEY."

ANN BAILBY . I live in Upper Thames-street. I was present at the prisoner's marriage in 1840—he was married to Hannah Butlin—they lived at our house after that—they might have lived two or three months there.
COURT. Q. How old was she? A. I cannot say—I believe about twenty-five.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you know her very well? A. I knew her when she came to our house to lodge—she was a servant—I have not
heard that the prisoner got any money with her-—I have not seen her since she left our house, which is nearly two years.

GUILTY . Aged 42.—
Transported for Seven Years.

849.
ISAAC LINTON was indicted
for embezzlement.

JAMES PAGE . I live at Merton—the prisoner was my carman. On the 28th of September I sent him to Mr. Evans's with a ton of potatoes and half a load of straw, which came to 2l. 9s.—I called some time after, and Mr. Evans was not at home—I then sent the prisoner—if he had received that money it was his duty to pay it me immediately—he has not paid it me.
DANIEL EVANS . I am a cow-keeper, and live in Dorset-square. On the 28th of September I paid the prisoner 2l. 9s. for Mr. Page
Prisoner. I put it into a purse with some of my own, 7l. 5s. in all; I lost it out of my pocket.

GUILTY . Aged 26.—
Confined Three Months.

850.
THOMAS EGGLETON was indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of September, 671bs. weight of lead, value 12s., belonging to the
inhabit
ants of the county of Surrey, and fixed to a building.—2nd COUNT, the same not stating it to be fixed.—3rd COUNT, stating it to belong to
Henry Heathcote Russell.

HENRY HEATHCOTE RUSSELL . I live in Freeman's-court, Cornhill. I am clerk of the works, and superintendent of the Lunatic Asylum for the county of Surrey—there was some lead missing about the 21st or 22nd of September, 1839—it was a portion of the ridge lead, gone from a tool-house in the kitchen garden—it had been cut in length, and taken away—about half a cwt. was left—the policeman brought the lead, in a bag on the 23rd of September—I compared it—seven pieces had been cut, which were worth 10s. or 12s.—five out of the seven were brought back—the prisoner had been employed as a labourer there, I believe during the month of September—the tool-house belongs to the Asylum—it was formerly the residence of Mr. Perkins, and the Magistrates of Surrey purchased the estate to build the Asylum.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. What were the works going on? A. Building the Asylum—Mr. Edward Lappenter, the architect, employed me—I lived there, in Mr. Perkins's house—I had the whole charge of the property.
COURT. Q. Had Mr. Perkins any thing to do with it during the time you were there? A. No.

JOHN WAYMARK (police-constable of Wandsworth.) I have known the prisoner twenty years—about eight o'clock on the 20th of September, 1839, I passed the prisoner in Garratt-lane, Wanda worth, about half a mile from where the lead was stolen—he had the bag produced with him—he turned up the lane to the Asylum—I did not speak to him—I am sure he is the man.

Cross-examined. Q. How do you know it was the 20th of September? A. I am sure of it—I saw the bag, soon after it was found in Mr. Martin's fields, with the lead in it—I was about two yards from the prisoner when I saw him in Garratt-lane—it was a light-looking bag, and he was carrying it under his arm—I did not tell the Magistrate that I met him with a white
bag which was quite empty, under his arm, and not the bag which has got the lead in it now.
COURT. Q. Did you notice the bag? A. Yes, under his arm—it was a coarse-looking light bag—there is no mark on it—this is the same sort of bag.

WILLIAM HEATH . I am bailiff of Mr. Martin. I was so in 1839—Garratt-lane parts the Asylum from Mr. Martin's land—Mr. Perkins parted with the land in 1838—he had nothing to do with it after the Asylum had begun building—I had not seen him interfering—he used to do so before—in September, 1839, I was in one of our fields adjoining the lane with some men and women picking up potatoes—it was twenty minutes to nine o'clock, on the 20th of September—Mr. Heath's factory-bell had rung half-past eight—I saw the prisoner come over the stile into the lane into our pre
mises—he had a bag on his back—he ran into the first field, and threw the bag and its contents into a ditch, and covered it with some nettles—I was about thirty yards from him—I went towards him, and met him face to face—I said, "What have you been putting in the ditch?"—he said, "It don't belong to me"—I said, "I suppose it is something you have been stealing; I suppose you have robbed some poor man's house? let us go and see"—we were going to the ditch—I got a little before him—he slipped behind me, and ran away—I sent a boy after a policeman, who came before the boy got back—there was a bag under the nettles with something it it.

Cross-examined. Q. Of course you told the Magistrate all this? A. I did, what I said was taken down, and read over to me, and I signed it—I had never seen the prisoner before that day—I swear to him because I took such particular notice of him—I have said I did not know, till I saw him again whether I should be able to swear to him or not.
COURT. Q. But when you did see him, you knew him? A. I knew him immediately—I have no doubt about its being him—there were three women, a boy, and two men in the field.

EDMUND BRUCE (police-constable V 19.) On Friday, the 20th of Sep
tember, 1839, I went with Heath to a ditch, and found a sort of fustian, light bag containing five pieces of lead—I was present when Mr. Russell applied them to the roof of the house—they agreed with the marks where the lead had been ripped from—there were seven pieces taken away—I searched for the prisoner—I could not find him—I did not know where he lived—I searched at Merton, Beddington, and round the country—the building is in the county of Surrey.
(The witness Heath's depositions being read, omitted to state that he had spoken to the prisoner.)

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Transported for Seven Years.

851.
JOHN FOX was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of January, 4lbs. of bread, value 10d., the goods of
Francis Turner.—2nd COUNT, stating it to be the goods of
John Barrett.

JOHN BARRETT . I am journeyman to Francis Turner, a baker, at Clapham-rise. I was delivering bread in Portman-place, Clapham-road, on the 17th of January—I left my barrow, and went down into a kitchen—I saw the prisoner going away—I came up, and ordered him to be taken
to the station, but there was no policeman to be found—he had two of my loaves.

JAMES SMITH . I am a stonemason, and live in Ebenezer-place, Clap
ham—I saw the prisoner take two loaves out of the barrow—I collared him—there was another with him, but he did not take any thing—he walked away.

Prisoner's Defence. I was looking for work—I met a young lad whom I knew by sight—he went to the barrow, and took these two loaves, brought them to me, and said, "Take them"—I said I would take them back to the barrow.

GUILTY*. Aged 17.—
Confined Two Months.

852.
EDWARD HATTON was indicted
for burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
John Dorrell, about the hour of five o'clock in the night, on the 31st of January, at St. Saviour, Southwark, with intent to steal.

JOHN DORRELL . I am a dealer in marine-stores, living in Redcross-street, in the parish of St. Saviour, Southwark—I have purchased things of the prisoner. Last Monday night I shut up at ten o'clock all safe—my wife and daughter and myself sleep in the house—my son and a friend sat up to watch—I came down about five o'clock on Tuesday morning—I thought it was six—I told my son it was six, and he might leave—he said it was only five—I went to bed again—I had not gone five minutes be. fore this happened—it was a quarter-past five—I had lost money before this, and could not account how it had gone.

RICHARD BROWN . I am a warehouseman, living in Cross-lane—I sat up two or three nights at this house. Between five and six o'clock on Tuesday morn
ing, I saw the prisoner get over the wall, which is ten feet high, and lower himself down into the back-yard—he then moved a tub which covered a grating, and lifted up the grating, and dropped himself down into the cellar—a friend, who was with me, let the grating down—we took a light and found the prisoner—he had gone from the back-cellar to the front-cellar, and had got his shoes off ready to come up Stairs—there is a way up from there.
FREDERICK LONG (police-constable M 100.) I took the prisoner.
(William Hatton, a labourer, gave the prisoner a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Transported for Ten Years.

853.
CHARLOTTE PENNYFATHER was indicted
for stealing, on the 26th of July, 3 sheets, value 6s.; 1 table-cloth, value 2s. 6d.; 1 shirt, value 2s.; 3 waistcoats, value 6s. 6d.; 1 coat, value 8s.; and 12 yards of ticking, value 6s.; the goods of
John Rye, her master.

JOHN RYE . I am a coachman, in the service of Mr. Sutton, of Dulwich—the prisoner was my housekeeper—she had no right to dispose of, or to pawn any of my property. On the 11th of January I missed these things produced, which are all mine—the prisoner absconded that day without notice.

RICHARD LAW . I am a pawnbroker. I have three sheets, two waist
coats, and one table-cloth—they were pawned by the prisoner at various times.
JOHN BRAGG . I am a pawnbroker. I have a bed-tick, a coat, and pair of trowsers pawned by the prisoner.
Prisoner's Defence. I owed a little money. I intended to get them out again. I gave the tickets up when I saw the prosecutor.

GUILTY . Aged 57.—
Confined Four Months.

854.
JAMES ELLIOTT was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of Ja
nuary, 7lbs, weight of suet, value 3s., the goods of
John Vooght, his master: and
SARAH SAUNDERS
, for feloniously receiving the same, well knowing it to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

ALFRED CAMP . I am apprenticed to John Vooght, a butcher, in Lark
hall-lane, Clapham. About half-past eight o'clock, on the 26th of Ja
nuary, I went into a timber-yard adjoining our premises, and saw a bundle of fat tied up in a handkerchief—I took it in, and my mistress opened it—I took it back, and put it into the same place—I believe it to be my master's fat—on my afterwards going to the spot it was gone—I fetched my master—he told me to watch in one place while he watched in another, and at a quarter-past nine he called to me—he said he had got the prisoner—I had seen the prisoner wearing such a handkerchief as the fat was in, round his neck that morning.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. You did not see him do any thing with it? A. No.

JOHN VOOGHT . The prisoner Elliott was in my service. On the night of the 26th of January I was out—my apprentice Camp came to me—in consequence of what he said I told him to watch—I saw the prisoner coming home—I asked him where he had been—he told me—I asked him what be had taken there—he said, "Nothing"—this is mutton suet.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Do you know Saunders? A. Yes—she is married—I had her husband taken up—we went before the Grand Jury, and they threw out the bill—she has just surrendered to take her trial—I went to Saunders, and found her husband at home.

GEORGE BECK (police-sergeant V.) I took Elliott—on conveying him to the station he said, "Oh, dear, will my master come?"—he said he hoped he would let him go, and he should not have taken it, if Mrs. Saun
ders had not come and asked him to give her a piece of fat—when I got to the station I took this handkerchief from Elliott—Saunders said, "This is the handkerchief he brought the fat in to me, and the basket is mine"—this is the basket and fat—I got them from Mr. Vooght.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Where did you take Elliott? A. At his master's shop—it was in the absence of Saunders that he told me she had asked him for the fat.

JOSEPH BIGG (police-sergeant V 8.) I went with the prosecutor to Saunders's house—she denied at first that Elliott had been there—I com
menced searching, and then she said to Mr. Vooght, "He has been here, and brought a little fat," and at the same time she gave him the basket, and the fat in it.

Cross-examined. Q. You mentioned to her that a boy had been there? A. Mr. Vooght asked her, and mentioned his name, and she said he had been there—her husband was in the room all the time—I went back and took him—the Magistrate admitted Saunders to bail, and she has surren
dered.
(Elliott received a good character.)

ELLIOTT—
GUILTY . Aged 16.—Recommended to mercy by the Pro
secutor and Jury.—
Confined Ten Days.

SAUNDERS—
NOT GUILTY .

855.
HENRY STRIPE was indicted
for embezzlement.

HENRY PHILPOTT . I live at Fulham, and am a publican. The prisoner was my pot-boy—it was his duty to pay me the money he received—if he received 1s. on the 3rd of January, or 6d. on the 4th, or 1s. on the 9tb, he has not paid it to me.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. How long had he been with you? A. Nine or ten months—I sent bills round, and by that means discovered the deficiency—there are other deficiencies—I sent him round with beer too or three times a-day—he ought to have paid me when he returned—I did not know every one that he sold beer to, but Mr. Stocking had his beer every day, and Mrs. Shinnick—the prisoner settled with me three or four times a day, sometimes, and sometimes not once in a week—he used to make excuses that people had not paid him—it was his duty to settle with me every time he came back.
FREDERICK JAMES STOCKING . I had beer of the prosecutor—I paid the prisoner every time he came—I paid him on the 3rd of January, 1s., and on the 4th, 6d.

Cross-examined. Q. Did it never happen that instead of paying him in the morning, you paid him in the afternoon? A. I paid him at one o'clock at noon, and at nine At night—a bill of 16s. 9d. was sent in to me, bat I had paid it all—I do sot think it has ever happened that I have paid the prisoner for the one o'clock beer at night—my wife has some
times paid him—I know I paid him 1s. on the 3rd of January, and 6d. of it was for the Sunday's beer, when we do not pay, and that I paid at nine in the morning.
MARGARET SHINNICK . On the 9th of January I paid the prisoner 1s.

Cross-examined. Q. How do you know it was the 9th? 2l."My mis
tress told me so—she was in the kitchen—I paid the 1s.—it was for Saturday and Sunday's beer, and it was on Sunday night I paid it—my mistress is always in the habit of paying regularly—a bill of 2l. 11s. 11d. was sent to my mistress, but I knew it was paid—I saw the bill, and had it in my hand.
(The prisoner received a good character.)

GUILTY . Aged 36.—
Confined Six Months.
ADJOURNED TO FEBRUARY 28TH.
